member.name: T:System.Text.StringHandler

summary.para:
Provides a handler used on two cases:
By the language compiler to process interpolated strings into instances.
As a builder to append and catenate multiple s to a whole one.
Different with , this type won't contain any formatters to construct any custom format operations, i.e. using .

member.name: F:System.Text.StringHandler.GuessedLengthPerHole
member.summary: Expected average length of formatted data used for an individual interpolation expression result.

remarks.para: This is inherited from , and could be changed based on further data.

actually uses format.Length + args.Length * 8, but format.Length includes the format items themselves, e.g. "{0}", and since it's rare to have double-digit numbers of items, we bump the 8 up to 11 to account for the three extra characters in "{d}", since the compiler-provided base length won't include the equivalent character count.

para.i: The original value implemented by .NET foundation is 11, but I change it to 8.

member.name: F:System.Text.StringHandler.MinimumArrayPoolLength

member.remarks: Same as stack-allocation size used today by .

member.summary: Array rented from the array pool and used to back .

target.i: The feature "Custom parameterless struct constructor" makes the parameterless struct constructor different with default(T). If you has defined a parameterless struct constructor, new T() is no longer with the same meaning as default(T).

member.name: M:System.Text.StringHandler.AppendLiteral(System.String)
member.summary: Writes the specified string to the handler.

remarks.para: is expected to always be called by compiler-generated code with a literal string. By inlining it, the method body is exposed to the constant length of that literal, allowing the JIT to prune away the irrelevant cases. This effectively enables multiple implementations of , special-cased on and optimized for the literal's length.

We special-case lengths 1 and 2 because they're very common, e.g.
' ', '.', '-', '\t', etc.
", ", "0x", "=>", ": ", etc.
but we refrain from adding more because, in the rare case where is called with a non-literal, there is a lot of code here to be inlined.

member.name: M:System.Text.StringHandler.AppendFormatted(System.Object,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Writes the specified value to the handler.
member.param: Minimum number of characters that should be written for this value. If the value is negative, it indicates left-aligned and the required minimum is the absolute value.
member.remarks:
This overload is expected to be used rarely, only if either:
a) something strongly typed as is formatted with both an alignment and a format.
b) the compiler is unable to target type to T.
It exists purely to help make cases from (b) compile. Just delegate to the T-based implementation.

member.name: M:System.Text.StringHandler.AppendFormatted(System.String)
member.summary: Writes the specified value to the handler.

member.name: M:System.Text.StringHandler.AppendFormatted(System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Writes the specified value to the handler.
member.param: Minimum number of characters that should be written for this value. If the value is negative, it indicates left-aligned and the required minimum is the absolute value.
member.remarks: Format is meaningless for strings and doesn't make sense for someone to specify. We have the overload simply to disambiguate between ReadOnlySpan<char> and , just in case someone does specify a format, as is implicitly convertible to both. Just delegate to the T-based implementation.

member.name: M:System.Text.StringHandler.ToStringAndClear
member.summary: Gets the built and clears the handler.
member.remarks: This releases any resources used by the handler. The method should be invoked only once and as the last thing performed on the handler. Subsequent use is erroneous, ill-defined, and may destabilize the process, as may using any other copies of the handler after is called on any one of them.

member.summary: Fallback for for when not enough space exists in the current buffer.

member.name: M:System.Text.StringHandler.Grow(System.Int32)
member.summary: Grows to have the capacity to store at least beyond .
member.remarks: This method is called when the remaining space _chars.Length - _pos is insufficient to store a specific number of additional characters. Thus, we need to grow to at least that new total. will handle growing by more than that if possible.

member.name: M:System.Text.StringHandler.Grow
member.summary: Grows the size of .
member.remarks: This method is called when the remaining space in _chars isn't sufficient to continue the operation. Thus, we need at least one character beyond _chars.Length. will handle growing by more than that if possible.

member.name: M:System.Text.StringHandler.GrowCore(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Grow the size of to at least the specified .

remarks.para: We want the max of how much space we actually required and doubling our capacity (without going beyond the max allowed length). We also want to avoid asking for small arrays, to reduce the number of times we need to grow, and since we're working with unsigned integers that could technically overflow if someone tried to, for example, append a huge string to a huge string, we also clamp to . Even if the array creation fails in such a case, we may later fail in .

member.name: M:System.StringExtensions.Reserve(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Reserve all characters that satisfy the specified pattern.
member.param:
The pattern that reserved characters satisfied. All supported patterns are:
@"\d" To match a digit.
@"\t" To match a tab.
@"\w" To match a letter, digit or underscore character '_'.
member.remarks: For example, if code is "Hello, world!".Reserve(@"\w"), the return value will only contain the letters, digits or the underscore character '_' (i.e. "Helloworld" as the result of this example).
member.exception: Throws when the is invalid. All possible patterns are shown in the tip for the parameter .

member.name: M:System.PointerMarshal.StringLengthOf(System.Char*)
member.summary: Get the length of the specified string which is represented by a *.

member.name: M:System.PointerMarshal.GetArrayFromStart``1(``0*,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the new array from the pointer, with the specified start index.
member.typeparam: The type of the pointer element. Note that the type should be in order to use pointer handling. Therefore, types shouldn't be allowed.
member.param: The length of the array that pointer points to.
The start index that you want to pick from.
member.remarks: For example, the pointer is the address of the first element in an array { 0, 1, 3, 6, 10 }, if parameter is 2, the return array will be { 3, 6, 10 }. Note that the parameter should keep the value 5 because the array contains 5 elements in this case.

member.param: The length of the array that pointer points to.
The start index that you want to pick from.

member.remarks: For example, the pointer is the address of the first element in an array { 0, 1, 3, 6, 10 }, if parameter is 2, the return array will be { 3, 6, 10 }. Note that the parameter should keep the value 5 because the array contains 5 elements in this case.

summary.para: Reverse all bits in a specified value.
Note that the value is passed by reference though the method is an extension method, and returns nothing.

member.name: M:System.Numerics.BitOperationsExensions.SetAt(System.Byte,System.Int32)
member.summary: Get an value, indicating that the absolute position of all set bits with the specified set bit order.
member.param: The number of the order of set bits.

member.summary: Get an value, indicating that the absolute position of all set bits with the specified set bit order.

member.name: M:System.Numerics.BitOperationsExensions.SkipSetBit(System.Byte,System.Int32)
member.summary: Skip the specified number of set bits and iterate on the integer with other set bits.
member.param: Indicates how many set bits you want to skip to iterate.
member.returns: The byte value that only contains the other set bits.

member.name: M:System.Numerics.BitOperationsExensions.SkipSetBit(System.Int16,System.Int32)
member.summary: Skip the specified number of set bits and iterate on the integer with other set bits.
member.param: Indicates how many set bits you want to skip to iterate.
member.returns: The short value that only contains the other set bits.

member.name: M:System.Numerics.BitOperationsExensions.SkipSetBit(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Skip the specified number of set bits and iterate on the integer with other set bits.

member.returns: The int value that only contains the other set bits.
